awd_titl_txt: Uncrowding, rehousing, and electronic migration of the mammal collection at the Denver Museum of Nature & Science
awd_abstract_narration:
An award was made to the Denver Museum of Nature & Science (DMNS) to: 1) purchase replacement cabinets to uncrowd and rehouse approximately 80% of the mammal collection; 2) support a full-time collections technician to assist with inventory, uncrowding, and rehousing of specimens, data validation, and database work; 3) migrate mammal collection records to the web-accessible, multi-institutional database, Arctos; and 4) continue to build on the exceptional record of delivering science and collections to the general public in a multitude of different ways. The mammal collection contains approximately 14,000 specimens that record 140 years of biodiversity and change in the Rocky Mountain and Great Plains region and beyond. Since 2006, the collection has experienced the greatest period of growth in the museum's 110-year history, including establishment of new frozen tissue and parasite subcollections. 

There is a strong suite of broader impacts associated with this project capitalizing on DMNS's role as the largest public natural history museum in the region. Due to the greater web visibility afforded by the database Arctos, the value of the mammal collection to the scientific community and public will increase along with the novel questions and methods being applied to museum collections from the fields of biogeography, biosystematics, community ecology, morphology, and biological informatics. The team will continue to build on an exceptional record of providing public access to view and learn about DMNS collections. The mammal collection will continue to be leveraged to enhance DMNS exhibits, visitor programming, and various educational programs. The team will utilize the Museum's large volunteer program, which unites the public with collections and science, to assist with project-related tasks. The mammal collection and its importance will be highlighted in a series of Scientists-in-Action satellite broadcasts that connect a curator with grades 4-12 students from the field or collections. Additionally, underrepresented high school students interested in careers in science will work in the mammal collection on research projects through the Museum's successful Teen Science Scholars Program.

The Denver Museum of Nature & Science (DMNS) is one of the largest natural history museums in the Rocky Mountain region with approximately 1.4 million visitors/year and over 1.5 million objects in its diverse collections. The mission of the Museum is to ignite our community's passion for nature and science. Coupled with this is a commitment to promote broader access to the Museum's collections, which are held in trust for the public.

In order to meet these goals, the Museum has focused increased attention and resources towards its stewardship responsibilities. Historically, DMNS collections have been housed in 49 spaces throughout the Museum, all subject to different environmental risks. To address these, the Museum completed a $56M facility in February 2014, with 63,000 ft2 dedicated to the Avenir Collections Center. This cutting edge facility provides modern, consolidated housing and workspaces for all museum collections with increased accessibility for the public. The Center also serves to enhance the Museum's dynamic science education programming in the adjacent, multi-level, Morgridge Family Exploration Center.

The mammal collection at DMNS includes over 15,000 specimens that document 140 years of biodiversity and change in the region and beyond. The collection continues to grow in part by the need to better document this biodiversity given the rapid influx of people into Colorado over the last 30 years, and tied to growing concerns over the impacts of environmental and anthropogenic change. The collection is an important baseline, as well as crucial future resource to address those issues given its long-term coverage of the region.

Funding from NSF allowed DMNS to enhance its commitment to the public and its collections. The objectives of the 4-year project were to 1) rehouse 80% of the mammal collection in new cabinets to improve storage conditions and address overcrowding, 2) support a full-time collections technician to assist rehousing the collection in the new Center, 3) migrate specimen records to the on-line, publically accessible database Arctos, and 4) support a successful distance learning program, Scientists-in-Action, directed towards engaging students (grades 4-8) in live, interactive broadcasts from the mammal collection.

NSF support also helped the Museum significantly improve stewardship and visibility of the collection. By the end of the funded project period, we were able to inventory, uncrowd, and rehouse over 80% of our mammal specimens into the new Center. A group of over 30 volunteers assisted in all aspects of the project and were essential in allowing us to exceed many of our goals. Over the course of the project, 7 high school and 3 college interns (including 1 NSF-REU student) also worked with the collection. In addition, because of project experience, our grant-funded technician was able to secure a full-time senior collections manager position at the University of New Mexico when funding ended.

Almost 15,000 mammal records are now available online through Arctos significantly increasing public access to invaluable specimen data associated with the collection. Since 2011, the collection has been searched over 95,000 times, spanning 3 million record instances. From Arctos, DMNS records are pushed to other large, public data portals such as iDigBio, VertNet, GBIF, BISON, and GenBank. This has expanded visibility and increased overall usage of the collection by the scientific community.

Over the course of the project, we engaged 1,750 students representing 41 schools and one juvenile correctional facility in 17 states and two countries through our live, interactive Scientists-in-Action program. Twelve broadcasts were conducted from the mammal collection with the final 4 directly from the new Center.
